Description
I'd like to propose migrating the project to use a src/ directory structure to improve code organization and align with TypeScript ecosystem conventions. This change would group all source code under a single directory while keeping configuration files at the root level.
Current Structure
ccusage/
├── index.ts              # Mixed with config files
├── calculate-cost.ts
├── calculate-cost.test.ts
├── data-loader.ts
├── data-loader.test.ts
├── logger.ts
├── shared-args.ts
├── types.ts
├── utils.ts
├── utils.test.ts
├── commands/
│   ├── daily.ts
│   └── session.ts
├── package.json          # Config files
├── tsconfig.json
└── ...

Proposed Structure
ccusage/
├── src/                  # All source code
│   ├── index.ts
│   ├── commands/        # CLI commands
│   │   ├── daily.ts
│   │   └── session.ts
│   ├── core/            # Core business logic
│   │   ├── calculate-cost.ts
│   │   ├── calculate-cost.test.ts
│   │   ├── data-loader.ts
│   │   ├── data-loader.test.ts
│   │   └── types.ts
│   ├── cli/             # CLI utilities
│   │   └── shared-args.ts
│   └── utils/           # General utilities
│       ├── logger.ts
│       ├── utils.ts
│       └── utils.test.ts
├── dist/                # Build output
├── package.json         # Config at root
├── tsconfig.json
└── ...

Benefits

Better Organization: Logical grouping of related functionality
Cleaner Root: Separates source code from configuration files
Scalability: Easier to add new features without cluttering the root
Convention: Aligns with TypeScript/Node.js ecosystem standards
Developer Experience: Clearer project structure for contributors

Implementation Plan

Create new directory structure under src/
Move files using git mv to preserve history
Update import paths throughout the codebase
Update build configuration in package.json
Update tsconfig.json to include src/
Ensure all tests pass
Verify build output remains unchanged

Changes Required
Import Updates: ~15 import statements need path updates
// Example: commands/daily.ts
// Before
import { loadUsageData } from "../data-loader.ts";

// After
import { loadUsageData } from "../core/data-loader.ts";
Configuration Updates:

package.json: Update build script to use ./src/index.ts
tsconfig.json: Add "include": ["src/**/*"]

Impact

✅ No breaking changes for npm package users (dist/ output unchanged)
✅ No API changes
✅ No runtime behavior changes
✅ Maintains co-located test structure

Questions

Would you be open to this organizational change?
Any concerns about the proposed structure?
Should we keep the current test co-location or prefer a separate tests/ directory?

Implementation Offer
I'm happy to implement this change if you think it would benefit the project. I can:
What I'll deliver:

Create a PR with all the necessary changes
Ensure all tests pass (bun test)
Verify the build works correctly (bun run build)
Test CLI functionality (bun run report daily/session)
Include the migration script I've prepared for transparency

My approach:

Fork and create a feature branch
Run the automated migration script
Manually verify and adjust any edge cases
Update documentation as needed
Submit PR with detailed description

I've already prepared a migration script that automates most of the work while preserving git history. Happy to make any adjustments based on your feedback!
Let me know if you'd like me to proceed.
Checklist

 I've verified this doesn't break existing functionality
 I'm willing to implement this change
 I've considered backward compatibility
 I've reviewed the impact on development workflow


Alternative: Minimal Migration
If the full restructure seems too much, here's a minimal alternative:
ccusage/
├── src/
│   ├── index.ts
│   ├── *.ts            # All other .ts files
│   ├── *.test.ts       # All test files

首先感谢作者开发的这个工具，他很有意思，我把遇到的问题向您反馈下。
Background
I discovered this ccusage tool on X.com and found it very meaningful for tracking Claude usage. However, I encountered some issues during local testing that prevented the tool from working properly.
Given my limited technical expertise, I sought assistance from AI to help diagnose the problem. The AI provided some analysis and conclusions, but I'm not entirely certain about the accuracy of its findings. I'd appreciate it if you could review the investigation and let me know your thoughts.

Problem
ccusage becomes completely unusable when the LiteLLM API service is down, failing with "fetch failed" error during pricing data retrieval.
Error Details
ERROR  Failed to fetch model pricing: fetch failed
Error: Could not fetch model pricing data
    at fetchModelPricing (pricing-fetcher.js:33:9)

Root Cause Investigation
Network connectivity test: ✅ Working fine
$ curl -I https://www.google.com  # Success
LiteLLM API status check: ❌ Service unavailable
$ curl -I https://api.litellm.ai/
HTTP/2 503
server: cloudflare
x-render-routing: suspend

$ curl -I https://api.litellm.ai/pricing  
HTTP/2 503
Conclusion: The issue is caused by LiteLLM API returning HTTP 503 errors, not user configuration problems.
Impact

ccusage becomes completely unusable during LiteLLM service outages
Users cannot analyze their Claude usage data at all
Tool has single point of failure dependency on external service

Proposed Solution: Multi-Source Pricing Fallback
Implement a robust fallback chain to eliminate dependency on single external service:
Fallback Chain Design
1. LiteLLM API (primary)
   ↓ (on 503/timeout)
2. Anthropic official pricing API
   ↓ (on failure)
3. Static Claude pricing file (GitHub/CDN)
   ↓ (on failure)
4. Local cached pricing data
   ↓ (on failure)  
5. Built-in Claude pricing table

Implementation Benefits

✅ Eliminates single point of failure
✅ Always functional, even when external APIs are down
✅ Uses most current pricing when available
✅ Graceful degradation with user warnings

Configuration Options
# Manual source selection
ccusage --pricing-source anthropic
ccusage --pricing-source cache
ccusage --pricing-source builtin

# Fallback mode indicators
ccusage daily  # Shows: "⚠️ Using cached pricing (LiteLLM API unavailable)"

# Tokens-only mode
ccusage --no-pricing  # Skip cost calculation entirely
Additional Improvements

Local caching: Store successful API responses with TTL
Retry logic: Exponential backoff for temporary failures
Status indicators: Clear warnings when using fallback data
User overrides: Allow manual pricing configuration

Alternative Data Sources

Anthropic: Official Claude API pricing endpoints
Static JSON: Community-maintained Claude pricing on GitHub/jsDelivr
Vendor pages: Scrape Anthropic's official pricing pages as last resort

Expected User Experience
# Current (broken)
$ ccusage daily
ERROR: Failed to fetch model pricing

# Improved (resilient)  
$ ccusage daily
⚠️ LiteLLM API unavailable, using cached pricing data (2 days old)
[Shows usage report successfully]
This architecture change would make ccusage much more reliable and user-friendly, ensuring it works even when external dependencies fail.

Bug Description
The --offline flag works correctly for the monthly command but does not work for the blocks command.
Root Cause
The issue occurs in two places:

In src/commands/blocks.ts, the offline parameter is not being passed to loadSessionBlockData():

let blocks = await loadSessionBlockData({
    since: ctx.values.since,
    until: ctx.values.until,
    claudePath: getDefaultClaudePath(),
    mode: ctx.values.mode,
    order: ctx.values.order,
    // Missing: offline: ctx.values.offline,
    sessionDurationHours: ctx.values.sessionLength,
});

In src/data-loader.ts, the loadSessionBlockData() function is not passing the offline parameter to the PricingFetcher constructor:

// Current code:
using fetcher = mode === 'display' ? null : new PricingFetcher();

// Should be:
using fetcher = mode === 'display' ? null : new PricingFetcher(options?.offline);
Steps to Reproduce

Run ccusage blocks --offline
Observe that the command still attempts to fetch pricing data from the API instead of using cached data

Expected Behavior
The --offline flag should work consistently across all commands, using cached pricing data instead of fetching from the API.
Proposed Fix

Add offline: ctx.values.offline, to the options object in src/commands/blocks.ts (line 151)
Change new PricingFetcher() to new PricingFetcher(options?.offline) in src/data-loader.ts (line 1059)

This matches the implementation in other commands like monthly which correctly handle the offline flag.

Problem Description
When Claude Code usage reaches a certain threshold within a 5-hour usage block, it displays a warning message: "Approaching usage limit · resets at 3pm." This message reveals the exact reset time for the current usage block. However, ccusage currently cannot utilize this information to provide more accurate usage statistics.
Current Behavior

ccusage appears to use a fixed usage window (possibly 11:00 AM to 4:00 PM based on the display)
Users cannot specify the actual reset time even when it's known from Claude Code's warning messages
The 5-hour usage blocks are based on when the user first started using Claude, but this information isn't configurable

Proposed Solution
Add a command-line parameter to specify the usage block reset time. For example:
ccusage blocks --reset-time 15  # Specify reset at 3:00 PM (15:00 in 24-hour format)
Use Case

2:00 PM - While using Claude Code extensively, the warning appears: "Approaching usage limit · resets at 3pm"
User knows the exact reset time is 3:00 PM (15:00) for their 5-hour usage block
User runs ccusage blocks --reset-time 15 to get accurate usage block statistics
Result - More accurate display of usage within the actual 5-hour blocks

Additional Context
When the usage limit is reached within a 5-hour block, Claude Code displays:
Claude usage limit reached. Your limit will reset at 3pm (Asia/Tokyo).

This confirmation of the reset time makes it valuable to have the ability to configure ccusage accordingly.
Benefits

More accurate usage tracking aligned with actual 5-hour usage blocks
Better understanding of remaining capacity within current block
Improved user experience for those who know their reset times
More precise monitoring of usage patterns within the rate limit windows
title: Feature Request: Add option to specify usage block reset time

The issue appears to stem from inconsistent width calculations across different parts of the rendering logic:

Mixed padding calculations: Different lines use different formulas for padding:


Some use boxWidth - 2
Others use boxWidth - 3
String width calculations with stringWidth() don't always match actual terminal rendering

ANSI escape sequences: The stringWidth function is used to calculate visible width excluding ANSI codes, but the padding calculations don't consistently account for the actual structure of each line.

Unified padding calculation: Attempted to use boxWidth - 2 consistently
Helper function approach: Created a padLine function to centralize width calculations
Content width abstraction: Tried to separate content width from box width

The terminal width changes
Different types of content (progress bars, text, formatted numbers) are displayed
The box contains Unicode characters (emojis, special symbols)

Terminal width detection: Ensure accurate terminal width detection

I found that since Cladue keeps running ccusage, and each instance of ccusage consumes several hundred megabytes of memory.
If ccusage does not return immediately, it will cause Claude to call it every second, resulting in a large amount of memory usage. For example, on my 16GB MAC mini M4, it was directly filled up by the 32GB cursor memory, forcing me to forcibly exit cursor (in fact, it was caused by the cmdline of cursor calling ccusage).
This is my ccusage-status.sh script. It creates a 60-second cache, which can effectively solve this problem:
#!/bin/bash

# Claude Code Usage Status Line Script  
# Displays usage information including model, session, and system metrics
# Version 4.0 - Integrated with ccusage statusline for cost metrics
#
# Color Support: This script tries multiple methods to display colors:
# 1. tput (most compatible with terminal capabilities)
# 2. ANSI escape codes (for color-capable terminals)
# 3. Unicode symbols (fallback for visual distinction)
#
# Debug mode: Set DEBUG_COLORS=1 to see which color method is being used

# Read JSON input from stdin
input=$(cat)

# Extract data from JSON input
model=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.model.display_name // "Unknown"')
model_id=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.model.id // "Unknown"')
session_id=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.session_id // "Unknown"')
current_dir=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.workspace.current_dir // "Unknown"')
project_dir=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.workspace.project_dir // "Unknown"')
version=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.version // "Unknown"')
transcript_path=$(echo "$input" | jq -r '.transcript_path // "/tmp/claude"')

# Get current time
time=$(date +%H:%M:%S)

# Get git information if in a git repo
if git rev-parse --is-inside-work-tree >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    branch=$(git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD 2>/dev/null)
    # Check various git statuses
    has_staged=$(git diff --cached --quiet 2>/dev/null || echo "true")
    has_unstaged=$(git diff --quiet 2>/dev/null || echo "true")
    has_untracked=$(git ls-files --others --exclude-standard 2>/dev/null | grep -q . && echo "true")
    
    # Determine git status symbol
    if [ "$has_staged" = "true" ]; then
        git_status="+"  # Has staged changes
        git_dirty=true
    elif [ "$has_unstaged" = "true" ]; then
        git_status="*"  # Has unstaged changes
        git_dirty=true
    elif [ "$has_untracked" = "true" ]; then
        git_status="?"  # Has untracked files
        git_dirty=true
    else
        git_status="✓"  # Clean
        git_dirty=false
    fi
    
    # Get ahead/behind info
    upstream=$(git rev-parse --abbrev-ref --symbolic-full-name @{u} 2>/dev/null)
    if [ -n "$upstream" ]; then
        ahead=$(git rev-list --count @{u}..HEAD 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
        behind=$(git rev-list --count HEAD..@{u} 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
        
        if [ "$ahead" -gt 0 ] && [ "$behind" -gt 0 ]; then
            sync_info=" ↕${ahead}/${behind}"
        elif [ "$ahead" -gt 0 ]; then
            sync_info=" ↑${ahead}"
        elif [ "$behind" -gt 0 ]; then
            sync_info=" ↓${behind}"
        else
            sync_info=""
        fi
    else
        sync_info=""
    fi
    
    git_info=" $branch$git_status$sync_info"
else
    git_info=""
    git_dirty=false
fi

# Get system usage information
memory_usage=$(ps -o pid,rss -p $$ 2>/dev/null | tail -1 | awk '{printf "%.1fMB", $2/1024}' 2>/dev/null || echo "N/A")

# Get cost usage information from ccusage
cost_info=""
if command -v ccusage >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    # Cache file to store cost info (valid for 60 seconds)
    cache_file="/tmp/ccusage_cache_$(whoami)"
    cache_age=60  # Cache valid for 60 seconds
    
    # Check if cache exists and is recent
    if [ -f "$cache_file" ]; then
        cache_time=$(stat -f %m "$cache_file" 2>/dev/null || stat -c %Y "$cache_file" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)
        current_time=$(date +%s)
        age=$((current_time - cache_time))
        
        if [ "$age" -lt "$cache_age" ]; then
            # Use cached value
            cost_info=$(cat "$cache_file" 2>/dev/null || echo "")
        fi
    fi
    
    # If no valid cache, update it (but don't wait)
    if [ -z "$cost_info" ]; then
        # Check if another process is already updating
        lock_file="/tmp/ccusage_lock_$(whoami)"
        if ! [ -f "$lock_file" ] || [ $(find "$lock_file" -mmin +1 2>/dev/null | wc -l) -gt 0 ]; then
            # Create lock file
            touch "$lock_file"
            
            # Run ccusage in background to update cache
            (
                # Build input for ccusage
                ccusage_input=$(echo "$input" | jq -c '{
                    transcript_path: (.transcript_path // "/tmp/claude"),
                    cwd: (.workspace.current_dir // "/tmp"),
                    session_id: .session_id,
                    model: .model,
                    workspace: .workspace
                }')
                
                # Get today's cost directly using ccusage daily command (faster)
                if cost_output=$(timeout 5 ccusage daily --json 2>/dev/null || gtimeout 5 ccusage daily --json 2>/dev/null); then
                    # Get today's date
                    today_date=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)
                    # Extract today's cost from the daily array
                    today_cost=$(echo "$cost_output" | jq -r --arg date "$today_date" '.daily[] | select(.date == $date) | .totalCost' 2>/dev/null || echo "")
                    if [ -n "$today_cost" ] && [ "$today_cost" != "null" ]; then
                        # Format cost to 2 decimal places
                        formatted_cost=$(printf "%.2f" "$today_cost")
                        echo " 💰\$${formatted_cost}" > "$cache_file"
                    fi
                fi
                
                # Remove lock file
                rm -f "$lock_file"
            ) &
        fi
        
        # Use previous cache if available while updating
        if [ -f "$cache_file" ]; then
            cost_info=$(cat "$cache_file" 2>/dev/null || echo "")
        fi
    fi
fi

# Enhanced color function with better detection and fallbacks
colorize() {
    local color="$1"
    local text="$2"
    
    # Debug mode - if DEBUG_COLORS is set, show what method is being used
    if [[ "$DEBUG_COLORS" == "1" ]]; then
        echo "DEBUG: Terminal: $TERM, Colors available: $(tput colors 2>/dev/null || echo 'unknown')" >&2
    fi
    
    # Method 1: Check if we have a capable terminal with tput
    if command -v tput >/dev/null 2>&1 && tput colors >/dev/null 2>&1 && [ "$(tput colors 2>/dev/null || echo 0)" -ge 8 ] 2>/dev/null; then
        [[ "$DEBUG_COLORS" == "1" ]] && echo "DEBUG: Using tput colors" >&2
        case "$color" in
            "cyan") printf "$(tput setaf 6)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "green") printf "$(tput setaf 2)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "red") printf "$(tput setaf 1)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "yellow") printf "$(tput setaf 3)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "blue") printf "$(tput setaf 4)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "magenta") printf "$(tput setaf 5)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            "white") printf "$(tput bold)$(tput setaf 7)%s$(tput sgr0)" "$text" ;;
            *) printf "%s" "$text" ;;
        esac
    # Method 2: Try ANSI escape codes if terminal seems capable
    elif [[ "$TERM" != "dumb" ]] && [[ -n "$COLORTERM" || "$TERM" == *"color"* || "$FORCE_COLOR" == "1" ]]; then
        [[ "$DEBUG_COLORS" == "1" ]] && echo "DEBUG: Using ANSI escape codes" >&2
        case "$color" in
            "cyan") printf "\033[96m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;      # Bright cyan
            "green") printf "\033[92m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;     # Bright green
            "red") printf "\033[91m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;       # Bright red
            "yellow") printf "\033[93m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;    # Bright yellow
            "blue") printf "\033[94m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;      # Bright blue
            "magenta") printf "\033[95m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;   # Bright magenta
            "white") printf "\033[1;97m%s\033[0m" "$text" ;;   # Bold bright white
            *) printf "%s" "$text" ;;
        esac
    # Method 3: Fallback to Unicode symbols for visual distinction
    else
        [[ "$DEBUG_COLORS" == "1" ]] && echo "DEBUG: Using Unicode fallback symbols" >&2
        case "$color" in
            "cyan") printf "🔷 %s" "$text" ;;      # Diamond
            "green") printf "🟢 %s" "$text" ;;     # Green circle
            "red") printf "🔴 %s" "$text" ;;       # Red circle
            "yellow") printf "🟡 %s" "$text" ;;    # Yellow circle
            "blue") printf "🔵 %s" "$text" ;;      # Blue circle
            "magenta") printf "🟣 %s" "$text" ;;   # Purple circle
            "white") printf "⚪ %s" "$text" ;;     # White circle
            *) printf "%s" "$text" ;;
        esac
    fi
}

# Determine git status color
if [ "$git_dirty" = true ]; then
    git_status_color="yellow"  # Yellow for dirty/changed
else
    git_status_color="green"   # Green for clean
fi

# Create colored output
output=""
output+="$(colorize "cyan" "$model")"
if [ -n "$git_info" ]; then
    output+=" $(colorize "$git_status_color" "$git_info")"
fi
output+=" "
output+="$(colorize "green" "$memory_usage")"
if [ -n "$cost_info" ]; then
    output+=" $(colorize "yellow" "$cost_info")"
fi
output+=" "
output+="$(colorize "white" "$time")"

# Output the final result
printf "%s" "$output"

bodyText:
Description
When running ccusage session , the tool incorrectly aggregates all sessions in a project directory instead of showing data for the specific session when the project directory name starts with a hyphen (e.g.,
-home-claude-user).
Current Behavior

Running ccusage session 7890f8b2-813b-4175-baa5-e5d18534c89d returns aggregated data for ALL sessions in the project
The output shows 880M+ tokens and $1320+ in costs, which represents the total of hundreds of sessions
The sessionId field displays as -home-claude-user instead of the requested session ID

Expected Behavior

ccusage session  should return data for only the specified session
The output should show tokens and costs for that single session only
The sessionId field should show the actual session ID requested

Root Cause Analysis
After investigating the source code, I've identified the issue:

The extractProjectFromPath() function extracts the project name from the path
For paths like /home/claude-user/.claude/projects/-home-claude-user/7890f8b2-813b-4175-baa5-e5d18534c89d.jsonl
It correctly identifies -home-claude-user as the project name
However, when looking up a specific session, the tool appears to aggregate all sessions within that project instead of filtering to the specific session file

Steps to Reproduce

Have Claude Code sessions stored in a project directory starting with a hyphen (e.g., .claude/projects/-home-claude-user/)
Run ccusage session 
Observe that the output contains aggregated data for all sessions, not the specific one

Environment

ccusage version: 16.1.1
OS: Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS
Node.js: v18.20.8
Claude Code project path: /home/claude-user/.claude/projects/-home-claude-user/

Evidence
Actual session file (132 lines, 385KB):
$ wc -l ~/.claude/projects/-home-claude-user/7890f8b2-813b-4175-baa5-e5d18534c89d.jsonl
132 lines
ccusage output (showing aggregated data):
$ bunx ccusage session 7890f8b2
sessionId: "-home-claude-user"
totalTokens: 880,076,357
totalCost: $1320.36
Proposed Solutions

Short-term fix: When a specific session ID is provided, use loadSessionUsageById() to load only that specific JSONL file, not aggregate by project
Better session lookup: Modify the session command to:
- First try exact session ID match
- Only fall back to project aggregation if no specific session is found
- Add a flag like --aggregate-project for intentional project-level aggregation
Improve path handling: Consider sessions in directories starting with hyphens as valid individual sessions, not just project aggregates

Additional Context
This issue particularly affects users whose Claude Code automatically creates project directories with names like -home-claude-user, which appears to be a default pattern in some configurations.
Workaround
For users experiencing this issue, you can analyze individual sessions manually:
cat ~/.claude/projects/-home-claude-user/.jsonl | 
jq -s 'map(select(.message.usage != null) | .message.usage) |
{
input: map(.input_tokens) | add,
output: map(.output_tokens) | add,
total_cost: "Manual calculation needed"
}'
Thank you for this excellent tool! I hope this report helps improve session-specific analysis.
title: ccusage session command aggregates all sessions

GLM-4.5 Model Support and Pricing Configuration
Problem Description
GLM-4.5 model pricing is not properly supported in ccusage, leading to incorrect cost calculations and discrepancies between expected and actual costs.
Current Behavior
When processing usage data for GLM-4.5 models, ccusage falls back to using pre-calculated costs from JSONL files instead of dynamically calculating costs based on GLM-4.5 pricing. This results in cost discrepancies such as:

Expected cost: 6.72 (based on GLM-4.5 pricing)
Actual displayed cost: 6.53 (based on fallback to pre-calculated costs)
Discrepancy: 0.19 difference

Root Cause Analysis


GLM-4.5 Missing from LiteLLM Database

GLM-4.5 model pricing is not available in the LiteLLM pricing database
Current pricing lookup only supports models in: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BerriAI/litellm/main/model_prices_and_context_window.json



Limited Provider Prefix Support

GLM-4.5 models exist in LiteLLM under different provider names:

deepinfra/zai-org/GLM-4.5
vercel_ai_gateway/zai/glm-4.5


Current DEFAULT_PROVIDER_PREFIXES only includes: anthropic/, claude-*, openai/, azure/, openrouter/openai/
Missing support for: deepinfra/, vercel_ai_gateway/



Model Name Matching Issues

When model name is "glm-4.5", the system can't find matching pricing because:

No exact match for "glm-4.5"
No provider prefix matches for deepinfra/vercel providers
Falls back to fuzzy matching which may not find the correct pricing
Ultimately uses pre-calculated costs from JSONL files





Expected GLM-4.5 Pricing
Based on available data:

Input tokens: 0.60 per million tokens
Output tokens: 2.2 per million tokens
Cache read tokens: 0.11 per million tokens

Proposed Solutions
Option 1: Add Provider Prefix Support
Add GLM-4.5 provider prefixes to DEFAULT_PROVIDER_PREFIXES:
const DEFAULT_PROVIDER_PREFIXES = [
  'anthropic/',
  'claude-3-5-',
  'claude-3-',
  'claude-',
  'openai/',
  'azure/',
  'openrouter/openai/',
  'deepinfra/',          // Add for GLM-4.5 support
  'vercel_ai_gateway/',  // Add for GLM-4.5 support
];
Option 2: Add Hardcoded GLM-4.5 Pricing
Add GLM-4.5 pricing configuration in the prefetch functions similar to other model-specific configurations.
Option 3: Enhance Model Matching Logic
Improve the model matching algorithm to better handle variations in model names and provider prefixes.
Impact
This affects users who:

Use GLM-4.5 models in their Claude Code sessions
Rely on accurate cost tracking and reporting
Need to budget and monitor API usage costs

Additional Context
The issue was discovered when users replaced Claude model references with GLM-4.5 in their usage data but noticed that cost calculations were inconsistent and incorrect. The system should properly support GLM-4.5 pricing to provide accurate cost analysis.
Files to Modify

packages/internal/src/pricing.ts - Add provider prefixes
apps/ccusage/src/_macro.ts - Add GLM-4.5 pricing configuration
apps/codex/src/_macro.ts - Add GLM-4.5 pricing configuration (if needed)
